urn:contentItem:460W-4P00-01G6-90B2-00000-00<published>2001-09-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T16:07:31Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>BUSINESS</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Skyservice Airlines emerges renewed from ashes of Roots Air forest fire'</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BY SUSAN PIGG</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">TORONTO (CP) _ In the 12 years since Skyservice Airlines Inc. got off the ground as an air ambulance and corporate jet service, Russell Payson has watched in awe as more than one desperately ill patient was rescued.</p><p nitf:lede="true">His airline _ now best known for its charter flights to the sunny south _ also airlifted the smallest premature baby from the remote North.</p><p nitf:lede="true">He's had to drop everything _ even opening Christmas presents with his family _ to fly a medical team to Baffin Island, into horrific''' conditions and bitter cold, to try to save the hands and feet of a frostbite victim.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> You name it, we've seen it,'' says Payson, 57, Skyservice's chairman and chief executive.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>CP</p></bodyText></section><p>He has not only piloted many of Skyservice's five air ambulances _ usually while a doctor and nurse slept in preparation for what lay ahead _ he has pitched in where he could to help stabilize a patient for transport.</p><p> It's just wild medicine. Until you see the stuff up there, you haven't seen anything,'' he says from the comfort of Skyservice's Toronto headquarters.</p><p>Payson also knows how tough it can be to make that final call _ to abandon all hope, to admit defeat.</p><p>He had to do that just four months ago when he grounded Skyservice's boldest business venture yet _ Roots Air _ less than six weeks after takeoff.</p><p> Funny enough, there's always some good that comes out of bad. I sort of look at it like a forest fire (aftermath). There are lots of green plants growing up right now. Things have never looked better.''</p><p>Skyservice's charter airline service, which whisks sun lovers to Mexico and the Caribbean each winter on behalf of Sunquest Vacations Ltd., plans to boost its fleet in the coming weeks from 10 aircraft to 15.</p><p>And Skyservice is expanding with unexpected speed into the wet lease'' business. Now, for instance, a Skyservice jet with Roots Air's logo on the tail is flying tourists to Turkey on behalf of a European airline, with Skyservice providing the crew, maintenance and other basic requirements.</p><p> I suddenly realized that it is very hard to sell from an empty store window,'' says Payson. All of a sudden (when Roots Air was grounded) we had five airplanes. We picked up a bunch of wet lease contracts almost instantly. It's a very nice, lucrative business.''</p><p>Next year he expects Skyservice will have six aircraft in Europe, a move that will boost not only the bottom line, but use of the airline's charter aircraft year-round.</p><p>Business is also booming on the corporate jet side. Skyservice owns and leases eight of its own corporate jets, but it also manages 15 others for Canadian companies and executives.</p><p> The forecasts are pretty optimistic (on the business jet side) for the next five to 10 years. The baby boomers are getting older, there are a lot more of them who are well to do and they're getting fed up with the whole airline situation,'' says Payson.</p><p>Increasingly, business people want to avoid airport lineups. They prefer to travel on their own schedule and companies are finding it just as economical to send, say, six executives on a private jet than fly them all business class on a commercial aircraft.</p><p>And that sector hasn't suffered because of the economic downturn, Payson says.</p><p> I find a lot of these organizations, when the going gets tough, they get going harder. It's brutal travelling. These guys are doing it three days a week. Suddenly it's no longer a perk, it's a way of getting things done.''</p><p>Payson has no plans to take the private company public. His goal is to focus on slow, steady growth''' and the company's fall move to a new facility being built as part of the $4-billion redevelopment of Pearson International Airport.</p><p> I must admit Roots was the only time we've ever looked at going into the high-risk domestic scheduled game. It didn't take us very long to make up our minds that we didn't like the look of it,'' he says with a laugh.</p><p>Few could have foreseen that charter airline Canada 3000 would buy Maritimes-based CanJet and Montreal-based Royal Airlines and launch a new domestic service that would make Canada 3000 the country's second-biggest airline.</p><p>The unexpected discount competition forced Roots into an untenable situation: selling most of its tickets right off at deep discounts.</p><p>Payson seems to have come to terms with that failed business venture _ the $7.5 million it cost, the chaos when a Roots Air flight had to be cancelled on the first day because one airplane wasn't delivered on time and another couldn't fly because of a botched paint job.</p><p>He has lots good to say about Air Canada despite the collapse of a $15-million deal _ announced the day Roots was grounded _ to be a partner in a new low-cost carrier that would have revived Roots as the national giant's long-planned low-cost carrier.</p><p>The deal was eventually scrapped. Air Canada plans to launch its own discount carrier later this year after opposition from its powerful pilots union, which viewed the Skyservice deal as a way for the airline to hire pilots at lower pay.</p><p> We came away with nothing but respect for the Air Canada people,'' says Payson.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Bruce Brophy.</p><p>-BODY- "It's right in behind the homes,'' said Brophy, a spokesman for Tantallon RCMP. "The location is the most serious because it's so heavily populated.''</p><p>Large billows of smoke hung over the area about 20 minutes outside Halifax. The fire was brought under control at one point, but strong winds whipped the flames up again.</p><p>One resident who had been asked to leave his home said flames were shooting up to 10 metres in the air.</p><p>Residents were sent to a community centre while firefighters battled the blaze.</p><p>Officials said no one had been hurt and no homes had caught fire.</p><p>Susan Mader Zinck, a spokeswoman for the provincial Natural Resources Department, said at least 40 hectares of forest were on fire.</p><p>At least two helicopters were dropping water on the blaze. Brophy said two more planes were due to arrive on the scene Wednesday evening.</p><p>Two busloads of school students were stopped from entering the area and sent back to their schools.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5WP1-52X1-JDH1-C566-00000-00It is dry times in these parts of Parry Sound-Muskoka2019-07-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:07:31ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 1It is dry times in these parts of Parry Sound-Muskoka

Looks like this is going to be one of those years that you hope to have a couple of beavers living in your creek.

Some of the back lakes and streams are now nothing but a trickle. I walked into a lake, with the canoe on my back, and it sounded like I was walking on cornflakes. The forest floor was bone dry. Judging by the pollen line around the edge of the lake. It has dropped very fast in a short while. You would of thought that by now there should have been some warnings about how dry it is in the bush. But I guess no one actually gets off the beaten trail to see the actual conditions in the woods.

Well it is out of sight and out of mind. But what I have seen tells me that we are primed for a forest fire. Lots of places are tinder dry and just waiting for some kind of spark.

That lake I walked into made for some fair fishing. By now the fish are all hiding in their summertime happy places. Next month will see that change a bit because the smaller lakes will become oxygen starved. This is just the normal part of the cycle in a small lake. The same thing happens in the winter months.

Just about the middle of February is when fishing gets tough in a lot of places. The ice has been on the lake a few months, the plants in the lake are dead or all most. When things begin to rot, it uses up the oxygen in the lake to decompose. The lake becomes oxygen starved and the fish stop eating until things improve. That is why the fishing picks up again in the spring and last until about now.

The bigger lakes give fish more options and places to move into when times get tough. We were fishing a lake last week for bass and never found a fish in water less than 15 feet deep. That surface water was too hot.

That rock face that dropped into 30 feet of water held a bunch of fish. The first fish was an accident, it came up to eat a surface bait. That was the one that showed us the school that was suspended 20 feet down. We had much better luck with twister tails and swim baits on a jig hook. If we got stuff down to them, they bit it.

That trout lake I was on did the same tricks. The fish were out in their same old places. I have caught them there before at this time of year. But you had to fish real slow and on the bottom. It was best to lay your fishing rod over the side of the boat and watch just the tip of your rod. Usually, when you think of trout, you think of a smash and grab bite. But these fish just taste and chew. By the time I left, they had got all of my worms. Only one made the mistake of holding on just a bit too long.

But things are looking up, soon it will be fall again and the fishing will get good once again.

Bill Eden is a columnist with Metroland Media. His column, Fish Tales, appears weekly. He can be reached at billandsueeden@yahoo.ca

urn:contentItem:5CWW-CP61-JBTY-W542-00000-00Nervous Timmins waits out huge fire2012-05-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:07:31ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. A10Nervous Timmins waits out huge fireBlaze largely contained, but town still at risk over the weekendThe Canadian PressTIMMINS, ONT.

Fingers are crossed that a shift in the weather will turn the tide in Timmins, where crews are battling a raging forest fire that's spewing smoke and ash toward the city.

Cooler temperatures and a sprinkling of rain have eased the situation but the danger remains, Mayor Tom Laughren said Friday.

The city of 43,000 is under a state of emergency and officials are on high alert. More than 225 people have been evacuated from rural communities including Hydro Bay, Kamiskotia Highway and Cooks Lake, Laughren said.

Many have sought shelter with the Red Cross, while others are staying with friends or family.

That's in addition to an evacuation order for the nearby Mattagami First Nation that saw 118 residents relocate to Kapuskasing on Wednesday.

"I think the next 48 to 72 hours, from a fire perspective, as it relates to Timmins, will be critical," Laughren said Friday.

Laughren said he hopes the skies will clear up enough to allow water bombers to take on the flames.

Premier Dalton McGuinty praised firefighters, emergency workers, leaders and volunteers for their work throughout the region. He paid a visit Thursday to Kirkland Lake, where crews have largely contained a massive forest fire that had been threatening the town.

On Friday, McGuinty expressed his admiration for those in northern communities like Kirkland Lake and Timmins, where his mother is from.

"A number of people have already been evacuated and about 90 per cent of those ... have not called upon the provincial government or the municipality to help them with their accommodation costs. They've gone to friends and family," McGuinty said Friday in Thunder Bay.

"That is a wonderful tribute to people in the north."

Kirkland Lake, about 140 kilometres southeast of Timmins, remained on high evacuation alert Friday. The community of almost 10,000 was dealing with high winds gusting up to 50 km/h.

Kirkland Lake schools were closed as a precautionary measure and municipal officials set up a $100,000 fund in case an evacuation is necessary.

Ontario's New Democrats have put their annual Northern Council conference - scheduled for this weekend in Timmins - on hold in light of the emergency.

The fire, roughly 30 kilometres outside Timmins, has also forced the closure of a gold mine operated by Lake Shore Gold Corp.

The Ministry of Natural Resources said high winds were fuelling the flames and there were concerns that strong winds could push significant smoke and ash into the community. The ministry was estimating the size of the Timmins fire at about 31,660 hectares.

No relief from extreme burning conditions was expected in the northeast of the province until at least Sunday, the ministry said.

Fifteen waterbombers, four Twin Otter aircraft and 56 helicopters are currently battling dozens of fires in the province. About 1,300 people are working on the emergency.

This forest fire has burned an area as close as 30 kilometres to Timmins. No break in the weather is expected until at least Sunday. Christine Rosche photo

The raging forest fires in northern Manitoba were far behind many evacuees today, but a smoky odor lingered in their clothing and the strain showed in their faces.</p><p nitf:lede="true">After a long night of buses, planes and waiting rooms, solemn and tired residents of Nelson House and South Indian Lake filed into a Winnipeg arena to fill out registration forms with the province's evacuation team.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"We just escaped from South Indian Lake at 4 a.m.," said Isabelle Linklater, 50, who travelled with her 80-year-old neighbors.</p><p>"There was lots of smoke and I have heart trouble," she said.</p><p>Almost 20,000 people have been evacuated out of northern Manitoba and the provincial government has called a state of emergencey.</p><p>Some residents described an eerie haze they saw as they fled the fires.</p><p>"We had to have the lights on in the day time to drive - the smoke was so heavy," said Fred Prince, 53, of Nelson House.</p><p>In the St. James Civic Centre, where more than 2,000 people have been registered since Friday, Red Cross staff and government social services workers handed out doughnuts, juice and pop and interviewed the people, often through a Cree translater.</p><p>Crying babies</p><p>Crying babies were placed on mattresses on the arena floor and men and women slumped over tables as they waited for a bus to take them to hotels.</p><p>Many of the refugees were airlifted out because of age or poor health.</p><p>Virginia Moose, 28, was able to bring only her youngest of eight children, 16-month-old Fraser, from their South Indian Lake home.</p><p>"I had a hard time breathing," she said. "I was told to leave Saturday, but I didn't want to leave my children. I call home every minute and they say don't worry."</p><p>Edward Donkey, 85, and his wife, Lillian, 60, of Nelson House, left their lifelong home with only a change of clothes.</p><p>Donkey, dressed urn:contentItem:5P3N-DKP1-F105-64HC-00000-00Milobar talks recovery2017-07-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:07:31ZLexisNexisBUSINESSMilobar talks recoveryKeith McNeill

The closure of Wells Gray Park and other impacts of the forest fire situation were the main topics on the agenda when Peter Milobar, the recently elected MLA for Kamloops-North Thompson, met with Clearwater and area tourism operators and other stakeholders on Saturday, July 22.

"The session was about how things unfolded and changes they would like to see," said Milobar. "We're going to work with BC Parks to see how we can minimize any damage going forward."

Several tourism operators whose businesses depend on the park have complained about quickly the park was shut down, especially considering that there were no fires in the park or its immediate vicinity.

The new MLA noted that this summer's forest fires have impacted a large area in the B.C. Interior.

He said he's been working with MLAs from other impacted communities to develop a post-fire strategy that will involve not just tourism, but also such industries as cattle ranching and forestry.

"We want to try to rebuild and not have a long, lingering post-fire recovery," Milobar said.

ST. JOHN'S, N.L. - Mohamed Ravalia thought his neighbours were out barbecuing on one of the first sunny summer days in St. John's when he caught the scent of smoke in the air early Monday afternoon.

Then he heard sirens, and looked outside to see flames shooting upwards behind the homes across the street in the heavily populated subdivision.

"For a moment, I couldn't see through the smoke and I actually thought one of the houses was on fire," Ravalia recalled, comparing the sight to images from Fort McMurray wildfires in 2016.

"You wouldn't think this would happen in good old Newfoundland," Ravalia joked, watering the grass outside his home on Orlando Street, where he and other residents were ordered to leave for a few hours as the fire department battled the wind and the heat as a forest fire encroached on the residential area.

The fast-moving fire was reported around 12:30 p.m. in the Kenmount Road area.

As the flames grew, a water bomber and a helicopter were called in.

Video images from the scene show large flames and heavy smoke inching closer to the neighbourhood as police moved door-to-door, telling people to evacuate their homes.

Some, like Ravalia, stayed with neighbours a few streets over, while others took shuttle buses to the Anglican church, where the Red Cross and Salvation Army provided food.

Later in the afternoon, emergency officials reported that firefighters had succeeded in getting the blaze under control.

By 5:30 p.m., residents were returning home, knocking on each other's doors to make sure everyone made it home safe.

Acting platoon Chief Scott Tilley said heat from the fire damaged the siding of 11 houses, but the house in the subdivision were spared.

"It was quite windy and quite a challenge today," said Tilley. "We're pretty confident now we're getting ahead of it."

He said electricity along Orlando Street will be gone "for some time" as utility poles were damaged in the fire.

The cause of the fire had yet to be determined.

Residents were asked to spray the outside of their homes in case the flames return during the night.

Jul 21, 2019( Digital Journal: http://www.digitaljournal.com Delivered by Newstex) Planes and helicopters joined nearly 2,000 firefighters in central Portugal Sunday to battle huge wildfires in a mountainous region where more than 100 people died in huge blazes in 2017.Some 1,700 firefighters and 400 vehicles were deployed in one of the biggest mobilisations ever seen in the area to fight the blazes in the heavily forested Castelo Branco region, 200 kilometres (120 miles) north of Lisbon, the rescue services said. Around 20 people have been injured in the blaze, including eight firefighters and 12 civilians, according to the interior ministry. One badly burned civilian was evacuated by helicopter to Lisbon.

The biggest effort -- 800 firefighters, 245 vehicles and 13 planes and helicopters -- battled to douse flames in the municipality of Vila de Rei. That fire "remains active", Interior Minister Eduardo Cabrita told journalists. Meanwhile, police said a 55-year-old man had been arrested in Castelo Branco suspected of setting a fire on the outskirts of the town, though this one was far from the main infernos. Authorities are looking into whether the fires may have been started deliberately, Cabrita said. "The cause of the fires is being investigated... there's something strange. How is it that five such large fires broke out in areas that are so close to each other?" he asked. The region's Civil Protection chief, Luis Belo Costa, said that "given the difficult terrain, we have not succeeded in getting the fire in Vila de Rei under control, but have only contained about 60 percent of it, despite a lull in the wind."The army said it was dispatching 20 soldiers and machinery to open routes "to facilitate access" for the firefighters. In a message, President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa expressed his "solidarity with the hundreds fighting the scourge of the fires".Two other forest fires reported on Saturday have since been brought under control.While a number of small villages were evacuated as a precaution overnight, no additional measures were planned on Sunday.But that could change "if the situation deteriorates," Belo Costa said.Five regions of central and southern Portugal were on maximum fire alert Sunday because of the dry weather and winds. - Highly inflammable eucalyptus - However, temperatures are currently below the threshold of 41 degrees Celsius (105 Fahrenheit) at which a red alert is triggered.The fires, fanned by strong winds, broke out on Saturday afternoon in the more inaccessible areas in the Castelo Branco region. The centre of Portugal is hilly and covered in dense forest and is regularly ravaged by fires, including the deadliest in the country's history when 114 people died in two separate blazes in June and October 2017.Much of the population in the area is elderly, as young people move to the cities. The forests are largely eucalyptus, a highly flammable wood used in the paper industry. Despite the combustion risks, the trees are planted because they are fast-growing and a major source of income for locals.With fields and pastures abandoned, the forests are poorly maintained, and the dense undergrowth facilitates the spread of the fires. According to the EU's European Forest Fire Information System, more than 250,000 hectares (620,000 acres) of land was destroyed by fire across Europe between January and April this year, compared with 181,000 hectares recorded for the entire fire season in 2018.
